Diffusion controlled stereoregular polymerization in granule reactors - Reaction kinetic of Pr/Bt sequence polymerization with TiCl4/MgCl2 Ziegler-Natta catalyst Meichen Han Conceptualization Data curation Investigation Writing – original draft 1 Yuanjin Zhao Conceptualization Data curation Investigation Writing – original draft 1 Shufang Luo Data curation Xunzhang Fan Investigation Aihua He Formal analysis Funding acquisition Supervision Writing – review & editing ⁎ Shandong Provincial Key Laboratory of Olefin Catalysis and Polymerization, Key Laboratory of Rubber-Plastics (Ministry of Education), Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266042, China Shandong Provincial Key Laboratory of Olefin Catalysis and Polymerization Key Laboratory of Rubber-Plastics (Ministry of Education) Qingdao University of Science and Technology Qingdao 266042 China Shandong Provincial Key Laboratory of Olefin Catalysis and Polymerization, Key Laboratory of Rubber-Plastics (Ministry of Education), Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266042, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Diffusion controlled stereoregular polymerization was studied to understand the relations between fragmentation and growing of catalyst granules and its catalytic features for olefin polymerizations. In this work, propylene (Pr) polymerization kinetics and Pr/butene-1 (Bt) sequence polymerization kinetics with spherical TiCl4/MgCl2 Ziegler-Natta catalyst were investigated by monitoring catalytic activity (CA), the number of active centers ([C*]/[Ti]) and microstructure of polymers. It was found that the increase in Pr polymerization time benefiting to the catalyst granule fragmentation, had different influences on the [C*]/[Ti] and catalytic efficiency (CE) for Bt-stage polymerization in different stage. Anyway, the isotacticity and weight-average molecular weight (M w) of isotactic polybutene-1 (iPB) fractions decreased gradually with the increase in Pr polymerization time. It was deduced that the easy solubility of polybutene-1 (PB) brought difficulties in further fragmentation of catalyst particles to expose more active centers, and Bt was more sensitive to the chemical and steric environment around the active species. This work provides further understanding of the catalytic characteristics of granule reactors in the initial polymerization stage, which will guide the novel polyolefin alloy production. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Granule reactor technology Polypropylene/polybutene alloy Ziegler-natta catalyst Polymerization kinetics Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As one of the most important inventions in polymer chemistry, Ziegler-Natta (Z-N) catalyst found in 1950′s encouraged the emergence of modern polyolefin industry and large scale production of high density polyethylene (HDPE) and isotactic polypropylene (iPP) [1–4]. The Reactor Granule Technology (RGT) developed based on porous Z-N catalyst granules [5] as reaction beds provides possibility for various polyolefin production [6–16], including PP alloy and ethylene copolymers. The final polymer particles copy the morphology of the catalyst granules to provide solutions to control the polymer particle morphology [17,18]. The fragmentation and growing of catalyst granules and morphological evolution of polyolefin particles based on RGT attracted lots of attentions in polyolefin fields [19–39]. The particle growth mechanism of polypropylene (PP)/ethylene-Pr copolymer rubber (EPR) alloys, especially the formation of EPR inside the PP subglobules [40–44] or at the boundary [7,45,46] of PP subglobules were controversial. Bagheri et al. [47] reported that changing the switch frequency had no effect on the microstructure and molecular weight distribution of PP and increasing the switch frequency reduced the dispersed EPR size. The gas phase polymerization time has significant influences on composition and chain structure of PP/EPR in-reactor alloys prepared by a periodic switching polymerization process [48]. Isotactic polybutene (iPB) with excellent resistances to creep and environmental stress cracking, high deflection temperature, etc., is generally used in hot-water pipes. However, some drawbacks like extremely slow crystal-crystal transformation at room temperature [49–51], unsatisfied crystallinity and low crystallization temperature [50,51] etc., limited the application of PB. In order to resolve the above problems and develop novel iPB based materials with excellent creep resistance, PP/PB alloys were accordingly synthesized by two-stage sequence polymerization with Z-N catalyst in our lab [52–54] based on the bulk precipitation polymerization technology developed for iPB synthesis. The active species formed in the first-stage Pr polymerization could initiate Bt second-stage polymerization subsequently [53–56]. The introduction of PP and PP-block-PB block copolymer components was confirmed to accelerate the form II-I transformation [57–60], improve the crystallization temperature and crystallinity of PB [59–61]. However, the two-stage polymerization process still have some unresolved questions. The first important one is how to obtain more active species to initiate Bt polymerization and then synthesize PB with higher isotacticity. Considering the crystallization induced solidification of PB is quite inferior to that of PP in the polymerization process [62], the rapid crystallization of PP in the first-stage polymerization promotes the fragmentation of primary catalyst granules, and the different Pr polymerization time yielding different amount of PP will definitely determine fragmentation degree of the catalyst particles with different void size and porosity, which lead to the different number of active centers and then affect greatly the subsequent Bt polymerization. Our previous work [54] reported that the monomers of the second-stage polymerization were formed on the boundary of subglobules, after the cracks in subglobules were filled completely, the active substances on the surface of subglobules continued to initiate polymerization and then the polymers enwrapped the subglobules. In this work, the first-stage Pr polymerization with varied polymerization time was carried out to evaluate its influence on the second-stage Bt sequence polymerization. Solvent extraction fractionation with diethyl ether (DE) and then n-heptane (C7) was conducted for the PP/PB alloy analysis. The fractions of PP/PB alloy were characterized with 13C NMR and GPC to analyze the stereoregularity of active centers for Pr and Bt polymerization in different stage. This work is expected to understand the influence of the active PP particles with varied porosity on the catalytic efficiency (CE) and isotacticity of the subsequent obtained PB by using TiCl4/MgCl2 Z-N catalyst, which help to find solutions for PP/PB alloy synthesis with higher activity and isotacticity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Butene-1 (Bt) and propylene (Pr) (polymerization grade, purity ≥ 99.5%), were provided by Chambroad Petrochemical Co., Ltd, Shandong, China. The TiCl4/MgCl2 type Z-N catalyst with 2.45 wt.% titanium were kindly supplied by Orient Hongye Chemical Co. Ltd. Triethylaluminium (TEA) was purchased from Yanshan Petrochemical Co. 2-thiophenecarbonyl chloride (TPCC) (purity ≥ 98%), was purchased from Ruinuo New Material Co., Ltd, Qingdao, China. The n-heptane (C7) was purchased from Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Factory, which has refluxed continuously over sodium under nitrogen for 48 h and distilled immediately before use. Other reagents including external donor electron (ED) were commercial products, were used as received. 2.2 Polymer synthesis 2.2.1 Synthesis of PP A 100 mL three-neck reactor was vacuumed dried and then purged with nitrogen thrice. Then precise amounts of n-heptane, alkylaluminium (triethylaluminium, TEA), ED, Pr gas (constant pressure was 0.1 MPa and was control led by solenoid valve) and TiCl4/MgCl2 type Z-N catalyst (Ti=1 mmol/L) were introduced into the reactor to start the Pr polymerization at 30 °C for a constant time. Then TPCC was injected into the reactor to quench the growing chains, which was kept stirring at 30 °C for 5 min. Finally, the polymer products were washed with ethanol containing 1% hydrogen chloride (HCl), filtered, and vacuum dried at 40 °C for 24 h. 2.2.2 Synthesis of PP/PB alloy The glass reactor was treated as described in 2.2.1. Then, accurate amounts of n-heptane, alkylaluminium (TEA), ED, TiCl4/MgCl2 type Z-N catalyst (Ti=1 mmol/L) and Pr (constant pressure was 0.1 MPa and was control led by solenoid valve) were successively added into the reactor to initiate Pr slurry polymerization at 30 °C for a constant time. Then the unreacted Pr was completely removed by reduced pressure at 30 °C. Then Bt gas (constant pressure was 0.1 MPa and was control led by solenoid valve) was successively filled into the reactor to start the second stage polymerization at 10 °C for a constant time. Then TPCC was injected into the reactor to quench the growing chains, which was kept stirring at 30 °C for 5 min. The PP/PB alloy products were washed with ethanol containing 1% HCl, filtered, and washed with plenty of ethanol, filtered, vacuum dried at 40 °C for 24 h. 2.3 Fractionation of PP and PP/PB alloy About 2 g PP was dissolved in 100 ml n-octane (C8) at about 80 °C. Then the PP solution was cooled to room temperature for complete crystallization and precipitation of PP. Then the C8 insoluble fraction (C8-ins) and C8 soluble fraction (C8-sol) were isolated by filtration. After completely drying, the C8-ins was further extracted with boiling C7 in a soxhlet extractor for 24 h. Finally, the C7 soluble fraction (C7-sol) and C7 insoluble fraction (C7-ins) were obtained. C8-sol and C7-sol fractions were collected by rotational evaporation and then precipitation with plenty of ethanol. Atactic PP (aPP), medium-isotactic PP (MiPP) and isotactic PP (iPP) fractions were represented by C8-sol, C7-sol and C7-ins, respectively [63]. About 2 g of PP/PB alloy was extracted with boiling diethyl ether (DE) in a soxhlet extractor for 24 h, and the DE soluble fraction (DE-sol) and DE insoluble fraction (DE-ins) were obtained by filtration. After completely drying, the DE-ins was further extracted with boiling C7 in a soxhlet extractor for 48 h. Then the C7 soluble fraction (C7-sol) and C7 insoluble fraction (C7-ins) were isolated. DE-sol and C7-sol fractions were collected by rotational evaporation and then precipitation with plenty of ethanol. Atactic PP/atactic PB (aPP/aPB), iPB and iPP/PP-block-PB block copolymer fractions were represented by DE-sol, C7-sol and C7-ins, respectively [54]. All the fractions were vacuum dried at 40 °C till constant weight achieved. 2.4 Sample purification The PP and PP/PB alloy samples quenched by TPCC were purified carefully to avoid the disturbance of impurities on the number of active centers ([C*]/[Ti]). Firstly, about 100 mg polymer and 150 ml ethanol were added into a 250 ml flask and kept stirring at 70 °C for 60 min. The suspension was then separated by filtration and the polymer solids were washed thrice with plenty of ethanol. Secondly, the above completely dried polymer samples was dissolved in 150 ml C8 at 100 °C, then the above solution was introduced into a beaker filled with plenty of ethanol, precipitated and filtered. Then the polymer samples was extracted with boiling ethanol for 12 h and then vacuum dried at 40 °C till constant weight [54,63]. 2.5 Characterizations The gel permeation chromatography (GPC) was operated on Waters GPC 2000 with 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene as solvent at 150 ± 0.05 °C to test the weight-average molecular weight (M w) and molecular weight distribution (MWD), calibrated by polystyrene standard. The carbon-13 nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometry (13C NMR) was conducted on a Bruker AVANCE III spectrometer at 120 °C with 1,2-dichlorobenzene-d4 as solvent and scanning times of 4000. The morphologies of the PP and PP/PB alloy particles synthesized at different polymerization conditions was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) on a JEOL-7500F instrument with acceleration voltage 3 kV. The differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) thermograms were recorded using PerkinElmer DSC 8500 with 4–6 mg of polymers. The samples were first heated from 25 °C to 200 °C with rate of 10 °C/min, kept at constant temperature for 5 min. Then, the samples was cooled to 25 °C with rate of 10 °C /min. Finally, the samples was reheated to 200 °C with rate of 10 °C/min. The second heating step was recorded for the melting point of the PP and PBA without residual thermal history to obtain the melting temperature (T m) and crystallinity (X c). The [C*]/[Ti] was determined by an ultraviolet fluorescence detector (YHTS-2000, Taizhou Yinhe Instrument Co.) though determining the sulfur contents in TPCC quenched polymers according to formula (1): (1) [ C * ] / [ Ti ] = [ S ] [ g P ] × 10 − 6 32 × Ti × 100 % [S] is the mass of sulfur (PPM), [gP] is the mass of TPCC quenched polymer (g), [Ti] is the molar mass of titanium (mol). The rate constant of chain propagation (k p) is obtained by formula (2): (2) R p = k p [ C * ] [ M ] In formula (2), R p is the polymerization rate (mol/L·s), [C*] is the concentration of the active center (mol/L), [M] is the concentration of the monomer (mol/L) [64,65]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Polymerization kinetics of PR and PR/BT with TiCl4/MgCl2-TEA catalyst Pr homopolymerizations and Pr/Bt two-stage sequence polymerizations were carried out with TiCl4/MgCl2 Z-N catalysts under different Pr polymerization time (Table 1 ). For Pr homopolymerization, both the catalytic efficiency (CE) and the number of active centers ([C*]/[Ti]) increased gradually with the increase in polymerization time within 30 min (black line in Fig. 1 a and 1b). The increased particle size with prolong polymerization time revealed the further enlargement and fragmentation of the catalyst particles, which resulted in more active center exposure (Figs. 1b, 2 ). As shown in Fig. 2a and 2b, the PP particles perfectly replicated the spherical morphology of the catalyst. Subglobules (red circled areas in Fig. 2) were clearly observed on the PP particles with size ranged from hundred nanometers to several micronmeters. Unlike PP/PB alloy particles in Fig. 2c and 2d, no fibrils were observed in the PP particles indicating the rapid crystallization of PP chains led to highly replicated morphology from the catalyst crystallites. The diameter of PP4 particles with 10 min polymerization time was significantly larger than that of PP2. However, the rate constant for chain propagation kp reduced gradually with increasing Pr polymerization time (Table 1), reflecting the diffusion controlled polymerization arising with increasing Pr polymerization time. The situation is quite different for PP/PB alloy synthesis containing Pr first-stage polymerization under varied polymerization time and then Bt second-stage polymerization for constant 2 min. Firstly, the CE increased gradually with the increase in Pr polymerization time when Pr polymerization time within 10 min. Secondly, the measured [C*]/[Ti] was much lower than that observed in Pr homopolymerization system and reduced slightly with the first-stage polymerization time increasing (red line in Fig. 1a and 1b). The differences observed in PP/PB alloy synthesis was attributed to the increased diffusion controlled polymerization of Bt, which was due to the much slower crystallization of PB from polymerization system compared to that of PP [55]. With the increase in Pr first-stage polymerization time from 1 min to 5 min, the in-situ formed PP chains, crystallized immediately, expanded the catalyst particles to expose more active centers. However, the PB yielded in the second-stage Bt polymerization crystallized and then solidified difficulty due to the easy solubility of PB in Bt monomers [62], which was also proved by the fibrations observed in the PP/PB alloy particles in Fig. 2c3 and 2d3. As shown in Table 1, it can be seen that 2 min Pr polymerization resulted PP2 with 3.6 mol% [C*]/[Ti], and then initiated Bt polymerization with 2.6 g/gcat catalytic efficiency (CE(PB)) and led to 0.7 mol% [C i PB*]/[Ti]. However, 10 min Pr polymerization resulted PP4 with 8.7 mol% [C*]/[Ti], and then initiated Bt polymerization with 0.5 g/gcat CE(PB) and then led to 0.5 mol% [C i PB*]/[Ti]. The contradiction between [C*]/[Ti] in PP particles and much lower CE(PB) revealed that the morphology of PP particles influenced the subsequent Bt activity. As Fig. 2c2 and 2d2 (enlarged circle in red) shown, some subparticles were connected by the fibrils in the high resolution SEM images of PBA2, while much larger agglomerates with no regular morphology were formed and covered the particle surfaces of PBA4. Therefore, the much slower crystallization rate of PB from Bt monomers resulted in too poor thrust to expand the catalyst particles, and the soluble fractions from PB increased the viscosity around active centers, leading the serious embedding of the active centers and then reduced CE for Bt polymerization (Table 1). 3.2 Solvent extraction fractionation and the fraction characterization In order to well understand the evolution of the active species with different stereoregularity varying with the increasing first-stage polymerization time, the obtained PP/PB alloys were fractionated by solvent extraction method into fractions including atactic components (aPP/aPB), iPP fractions icluding isotactic polypropylene (iPP) and minor poly(propylene-b-butene) (PP-b-PB) block copolymers, and isotactic polybutene (iPB) fractions [54]. It seemed that the atactic component content reduced obviously with the increase in Pr polymerization time (Table 1, Fig. 3 a). The PP1 and PP4 showed percentage of quaternary meso placement (mmmm%) about 93.9% and 91.1%, respectively. The iPP fractions in PBA1-PBA4 showed mmmm% about 92. 1%−95.2% (Table 1, Fig. 3b, c). When the Pr polymerization time was 5 min, iPP showed the highest mmmm% (95.2%). The M w and MWD of these iPP fractions were in the range of 50 × 104–80 × 104 and 4–6, respectively (Table 1, Fig. 4 a, c). However, with the increase in Pr polymerization time, the mmmm% of iPB fractions in PBA samples decreased from about 91.7% to 62.1% (Table 1, Fig. 3b, d), and the M w of these iPB fractions decreased from 64 × 104 to 33 × 104 and the MWD were in the range of 7–9 (Table 1, Fig. 4b, c). These reflected that those active centers yielding iPP fractions showed almost unchanged isotacticity and increased molecular weight features with increased Pr polymeirzation time. However, those active centers yielding iPB fractions during the second polymerization stage showed reduced isotacticity and reduced molecular weight features with increased Pr polymerization time. The chain structures including stereoregularity and molecular weight of polymer do affect the melting temperature (T m) and crystallinity (X c) of polymers. As Fig. 4d shown, the iPP fractions in PBA showed T m around 157–165 °C, while iPB fractions showed decreased T m from 105 °C to 96 °C with increased Pr polymerization time. The about 10 °C differences further proved the reduced stereoregularity of iPB fractions when the Pr polymerization time increased from 1 min to 10 min. 3.3 Discussions As depicted in the Fig. 5 , for Pr/Bt two-stage sequence polymerizations, the first-stage Pr polymerization time had great influences on the second stage Bt polymerization. The increase in first-stage Pr polymerization time from 1 to 10 min formed more active particle-reactors. The much faster crystallization of PP once produced provided enough pressure to fragment the catalyst granules and then expose more active centers. Therefore, both CE and [C*]/[Ti] increased with the increased polymerization time for the first-stage Pr polymerization. However, the active species formed in 1–2 min first-stage polymerization time showed relatively high CE(PB) and [C*]/[Ti] for the second-stage Bt polymerization, and then decreased gradually with a further increase in Pr polymerization time (Fig. 5a). The differences between Pr-stage and Bt-stage polymerization were attributed to the diffusion controlled polymerization from Bt monomers. Compared to PP, the relatively high solubility of PB in monomers led to the problems. However, the formed PBA1 with 1 min Pr polymerization time showed the highest isotacticity, and the mmmm% of iPP and iPB fractions in PBA1 were 92.6% and 91.7%, respectively. The increased Pr polymerization time had little influences on the isotacticity and M w of iPP fractions, but resulted in reduced isotacticity and M w of iPB fractions (Fig. 5b). It is generally accepted that the solid Z-N catalyst particles composed of TiCl4 supported on MgCl2 crystals have varied active catalytic species, which show different catalytic behaviors for different monomers and form polymers with different stereoregularity and stereodefect distribution [63,66–68]. For the two-stage sequential polymerization, the catalyst particles were expanded and more active species were exposed with the increase in the first-stage Pr polymerization time. The second-stage Bt monomers might be more sensitive to the some newly exposed active species with slightly different or changed chiral environment and steric hindrance, like desorption of ED or dialkylaluminium chloride (AlR2Cl) around the active Ti species [69–72], thus would lead the existence of poorly isotactic Ti species. In other words, more stable absorption from ED or AlR2Cl (by products from alkylaluminium) nearby the Ti species was recommended to construct isotactic active species for Bt isotactic propagation. 4 Conclusions In the process of Pr/Bt sequence polymerization activated by TiCl4/MgCl2 Z-N catalyst, the increase in Pr polymerization time resulted in increased [C*]/[Ti] and CE for Pr polymerization, and relatively high isotacticity and M w of iPP fractions. The increased Pr polymerization time was benefit to the fragmentation of catalyst particles and formed more active centers in the first Pr polymerization stage. However, the increase in Pr polymerization time, caused slightly increase in the first 2 min, and then decrease in [C*]/[Ti] and CE for Bt polymerization with further increase in Pr polymerization, while the isotacticity and M w of iPB fractions decreased gradually with the increase in Pr polymerization time. It was believed that the much slower crystallization rate of PB from the polymerization system brought difficulties in the catalyst granule fragmentation and more active center exposure. Compared to Pr polymerization, Bt was more sensitive to the chiral environment and steric hindrance around the active species changed during the polymerization process. It was deduced that more stable absorption of ED or AlR2Cl (by products from alkylaluminium) nearby the Ti species was preferred for iPB synthesis. coredata.dc:description: Diffusion controlled stereoregular polymerization was studied to understand the relations between fragmentation and growing of catalyst granules and its catalytic features for olefin polymerizations. In this work, propylene (Pr) polymerization kinetics and Pr/butene-1 (Bt) sequence polymerization kinetics with spherical TiCl4/MgCl2 Ziegler-Natta catalyst were investigated by monitoring catalytic activity (CA), the number of active centers ([C*]/[Ti]) and microstructure of polymers. It was found that the increase in Pr polymerization time benefiting to the catalyst granule fragmentation, had different influences on the [C*]/[Ti] and catalytic efficiency (CE) for Bt-stage polymerization in different stage. Anyway, the isotacticity and weight-average molecular weight (M w) of isotactic polybutene-1 (iPB) fractions decreased gradually with the increase in Pr polymerization time. It was deduced that the easy solubility of polybutene-1 (PB) brought difficulties in further fragmentation of catalyst particles to expose more active centers, and Bt was more sensitive to the chemical and steric environment around the active species. This work provides further understanding of the catalytic characteristics of granule reactors in the initial polymerization stage, which will guide the novel polyolefin alloy production.
coredata.dc:title: Diffusion controlled stereoregular polymerization in granule reactors - Reaction kinetic of Pr/Bt sequence polymerization with TiCl4/MgCl2 Ziegler-Natta catalyst
